awd_titl_txt: Relational Beliefs and Expectations in Early Adolescence as Predictors of School and Social Competence
awd_abstract_narration:
Children's beliefs and expectations about their relationships with their parents are related to their ability to adapt to new situations, experiences, and relationships, including those with peers and teachers. The goal of this project is to investigate the link between children's understanding of their relationships with their parents and their ability to adapt to the challenges of early adolescence.  Early adolescence is a period of significant change in children's family dynamics as they begin to pursue autonomy and an independent identity.  Young adolescents also encounter new social and academic challenges as they navigate the transition to middle school. This project will evaluate how youths' thoughts and feelings about their relationships with their mothers relate to their own self-concept, self-regulation, school adjustment, and social competence. The outcomes will be compared to these children's same measures at earlier points in their development.

This project will extend an ongoing NSF-supported study of 250 mother-child dyads (50% female children; 95.2% longitudinal retention) from multiple ethnoracial groups (88.8% non-White) and variable risk backgrounds (e.g., 36.7% poverty, 28% maltreated) who completed laboratory and school assessments of representation, adjustment, and parent-child relationship quality at ages 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 10. The current funds will support an early adolescent data wave at age 12 to assess multiple facets of youths' representations in terms of what they think and feel (i.e., the content of their representation) and how they organize their thoughts and feelings (i.e., the coherence of representation) to understand how representational processes may carry experience from the family setting to broader educational and social contexts. In addition to evaluating core developmental assumptions, expected scientific tools and findings will refine contemporary risk identification and screening approaches by providing efficient and culturally valid assessment tools that can be readily transported to clinical and field (e.g., school) settings.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this ongoing longitudinal study is to evaluate children?s representations (i.e., the content and coherence of their beliefs and expectations about relationships with parents and others) and children?s regulation skills (i.e., their abilities to redirect, modify, and control their emotional, behavioral, and physiologic arousal) as related to their multi-domain competence with regard to educational, interpersonal, socioemotional, and physical health outcomes across middle childhood and into adolescence. A major focus for this study is to understand how these systems (i.e., representation and regulation) influence children?s capacities to navigate difficult life experiences, such as child maltreatment, poverty, and ethnic-racial discrimination, as well as processes that support or hinder children?s expression of resilience (i.e., better-than-expected adjustment outcomes) across time and settings. This grant supported a comprehensive wave of data collection at age 12 and the extension of our research beyond preschool and early childhood, across middle childhood and into early adolescence. Findings from this research provide novel insights into specific and modifiable developmental processes that account for children?s strengths and struggles during a crucial phase of life, namely the transition to adolescence.

The current study built on six waves of prior data collection with 250 children (50% female; 46% Latinx) and their primary caregivers at ages 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 10 to include a new and comprehensive assessment of representation, regulation, and adaptation in early adolescence (age 12) using extensive laboratory-administered measures, as well as teacher-reports of children?s adjustment at school. Results document the significance of children?s beliefs and expectations about themselves and others as powerful mechanisms by which experiences within the family are carried across settings (e.g., to school and outside relationships with peers and teachers) and time (e.g., from early childhood through middle childhood). In addition, innovative measures of parents? representations of the parent-child relationship demonstrate that representational processes can explain intergenerational trauma effects from parents? own history of caregiving to their parenting practices in the next generation and, ultimately, to children?s representations and adaptation. Finally, this research also documents the integral connection between representation and regulation by illustrating how children?s relational representations can support (or thwart) their multi-domain self-regulation and adaptation.

Together, these findings offer crucial insights for parents, educators, and practitioners. In particular, research supported by this grant demonstrates not only how children?s and parents? internalized representations can influence adaptation, but also their likely modifiability via intervention. Importantly, the obtained findings also highlight the significance of cultural- and contextual influences on children?s development and adaptation with particularly notable implications for understanding expressions of resilience in the wake of difficult life experiences, and in diverse contexts. Thus, this research will advance extant efforts to promote success and wellness for all children, particularly those from backgrounds of disproportionate risk and disadvantage. Both representation and regulation resources are important for development and both can be modified by features of the surrounding environment. Thus, these processes are profitable sites for contextually and developmentally sensitive intervention efforts aimed at promoting positive development and mitigating the negative impacts of risk or adversity.

 


Last Modified: 09/12/2020
Modified by: Tuppett M Yates
